Dear All,

- https://github.com/Pipoline/rocket-python

Do you know which I should I choose? what's the difference?

Thanks in advance,
Austin

items.title: users_get_avatar when unauthorized
items.body:
You can enable the setting AvatarBlockUnauthorizedAccess for the avatars of the users to not be publicly available by everyone on the internet. It's an almost always basic feature to activate.

Sadly, the link you get back from the API (/avatars/username) cannot deal with the headers we send to the API to authenticate (X-Auth-Token), so blocking you from accessing your avatar. It needs rc_uid and rc_token in the Cookies, not the Headers....

Currently, in users_get_avatar, you get back a link. At the end of the method, you access that link, returning the response not from the API, but the image itself.
When we enabled the unauthorized_access-setting, the response will be a 403 - Forbidden. Seeing as we want to get the image, we could check for a 403 in the users_get_avatar-method in the end and in that case forge a request containing the token from rocket.headers as cookies.

Would you think this is too much automation in a single method, or should I do a PR for this?

items.title: channels_join API method missing

The API endpoint [channels.join](https://rocket.chat/docs/developer-guides/rest-api/channels/join/) is missing.
I'll do a PR.

items.title: Do not call logging.basicConfig()
items.body:
Hey,

I believe that calling logging.basicconfig() inside packages should be treated as anti-pattern.

As basicConfig() can be called only once, importing this package may cause basicConfig in the projects to not be processed and thus logging to not work in not an obvious way.

More information on how to do it properly can be found here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27016870/how-should-logging-be-used-in-a-python-package
https://docs.python.org/3/howto/logging.html#configuring-logging-for-a-library

Important note from docs:

> Note It is strongly advised that you do not add any handlers other than NullHandler to your library’s loggers. This is because the configuration of handlers is the prerogative of the application developer who uses your library. The application developer knows their target audience and what handlers are most appropriate for their application: if you add handlers ‘under the hood’, you might well interfere with their ability to carry out unit tests and deliver logs which suit their requirements.

logging.basicConfig() does exactly that, creates a handler.

items.title: rooms_upload fails to recognize mime time (and improvement suggestion)
items.body:
When uploading a relatively simple jpg file, the correct mime type was not recognized and it was uploaded as text file.

To try a solution, I reimplemented the method using the magic library and it worked:

```
class RocketREST(RocketChat):
    "Improvements on the RocketChat REST API"

    def rooms_upload(self, rid, filename, up_name=None, **kwargs):
        """
        Post a message with attached file to a dedicated room.
        """
        if not up_name:
            up_name = os.path.basename(filename)
        files = {
            'file': (up_name, open(filename, 'rb'),
                    magic.from_file(filename, mime=True))}
        # print("Object dict:", self.__dict__)
        return self._RocketChat__call_api_post('rooms.upload/' + rid,
                    kwargs=kwargs,
                    use_json=False,
                    files=files)
```

As a suggestion, I also introduced an optional up_name argument (filename to be given to rocket.chat), for added flexibility.


Am I doing something wrong or is the library not up to date?

items.title: Different instances with different users not possible
items.body:
Hey,

due to the headers being declared like this, it is not possible to have multiple RocketChat instances with different users.
```python
class RocketChat:
    headers = {}
```
By creating and logging in with the second instance the headers of the first get overwritten. This can simple be fixed by moving the second line into the `__init__()`.

items.title: Workaround for broken LDAP authentication
items.body:
Yes, authentication over the REST API fails when Rocket.chat is configured to use LDAP. Link to the main issue: https://github.com/RocketChat/Rocket.Chat/issues/4961

Obviously, this is not an issue for this project, but since the bug fixing at Rocket.chat moves with glacial speed, a workaround would be nice.

To get REST API LDAP authentication to work, I subclasses RocketChat with a new subclass, RocketChatLDAP, which uses some undocumented parameters. Naturally, this RocketChatLDAP class can only be used when LDAP authentication is in use.

Here's the code which I used as a fix in my client:

```
import json
import requests
from rocketchat_API.rocketchat import RocketChat
from rocketchat_API.APIExceptions.RocketExceptions import RocketConnectionException, RocketAuthenticationException, RocketMissingParamException

class RocketChatLDAP(RocketChat):
    def login(self, user, password):
        login_request = requests.post(self.server_url + self.API_path + 'login',
                                      data=json.dumps({'username': user,
                                            #'password': password,
                                            'ldap': True,
                                            'ldapPass': password,
                                            'ldapOptions': {}}),
                                      verify=self.ssl_verify,
                                      proxies=self.proxies)
        if login_request.status_code == 401:
            raise RocketAuthenticationException()

        if login_request.status_code == 200:
            if login_request.json().get('status') == "success":
                self.headers['X-Auth-Token'] = login_request.json().get('data').get('authToken')
                self.headers['X-User-Id'] = login_request.json().get('data').get('userId')
                return login_request
            else:
                raise RocketAuthenticationException()
        else:
            raise RocketConnectionException()

rocket = RocketChatLDAP('username', 'password', server_url='https://my.rocket.chat.url', ssl_verify=True)
```

While it might, technically, be possible to add this subclass to the main source, I somewhat question the wisdom of doing so. It is meant to be temporary fix or workaround, until Rocket.chat gets the issue fixed for real.

But it might be a helpful addition to the documentation for people having issues with LDAP authentication over the REST API.

items.title: Default log level - DEBUG

items.title: TOTP missing in auth request

RocketChat supports TOTP, and currently this wrapper is missing possibility to add TOTP token to auth.
More details:
https://rocket.chat/docs/developer-guides/rest-api/authentication/login/#example-call---when-two-factor2fa-authentication-is-enabled

However there's [Oct 20, 2017 commit](https://github.com/jadolg/rocketchat_API/commit/f1abebc8d0a76b533ee605f7aa614a872a7c7679#diff-04c6e90faac2675aa89e2176d2eec7d8) from @comodoro with change in exactly opposite direction. Maybe @comodoro has more info on why he proposed the change?

items.title: Git tags for releases
items.body: I'm personally used to tagging commits in Git before releasing to Pypi. This way it is easier to understand what's in a specific version you install using pip. I see there are not tags after 0.6.2 (the current Pypi release is 0.6.9)

items.title: ImportError: cannot import name 'RocketMissingParamException' after upgrade in pip
items.body:
Hello!

After using this Python Wrapper for a while during several months without issues I find that after updating today using 

``pip install rocketchat_API --upgrade``

I get:

```
File "xxxx.py", line 13, in <module>
from rocketchat_API.rocketchat import RocketChat
File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rocketchat_API/rocketchat.py", line 5, in <module>
from rocketchat_API.APIExceptions.RocketExceptions import RocketConnectionException, RocketAuthenticationException, \
ImportError: cannot import name 'RocketMissingParamException'
```
In:
Python version: 3.6.4 (default, Dec 21 2017, 01:29:34)  [GCC 6.3.0 20170516]

Same identical source code and enviroment was working till today after this upgrade.

Any tips?
